text: Good morning, everybody. Welcome to the service delivery bus. Great to have your faces in front of me. Not a huge agenda today. And then we're breaking and having some publicly excluded workshops. So that is good. I have an apology from the mayor today. I think everybody else is on board. I'm happy to move that apology in a second, please. Just put your hand up. Thank you, Bruce. All those in favour say aye.  Aye. Aye. OK. Disclosure of members' interest. Mike, I don't think the one you talked about is my agenda, so we'll let that one slide. Yeah, thank you. No conflicts there, late items. Now, as yesterday morning, I received an email from Liz regarding, it came from Ange and Chris, and I would like that to be part of this conversation of the CCTV, but I'm,  I realize that probably not many of you have seen it thinking, Liz, it's spread far and wide. Can I, can I, do I understand what they're talking about or no? So it's been copied to Brian and today, this morning to Dawn. It may be valuable. I don't know. I'm not a techno person. All the things I've got in it are beyond me.  Dawn, did you want to just, what did you want to do with it? Just add additional, what do you think?

text: Yes, I'll be handling this, Graeme. Thank you very much. And I've also got Sergei on the line also, if there's any questions about any of the camera locations or other things. OK, OK. Good morning, Sergei.
speaker: manager

text: Welcome to our meeting.
speaker: chairperson

text: Right. Yes. So, in the agenda paper, page 22, I just outlined here that this is a draft programme of CCTV improvement work over the next three years of the LTP. And I  take on board, I heard your earlier conversation about the letter or I've got a copy of an email from Ange Holt, which is dated Monday, 18th of October, to Liz, where she was talking about the camera improvements that she has previously discussed with the wider CCTV group and the things that she wants to see.  So that's not in conflict with what's in this paper. In this paper, we talk about the CCTV programme of improvements that was previously put forward by the  advisory group, including Police and ComSafe, in which Ange and others have been involved with that group. And the reason it is still noted as a draft programme of work is there's still discussions to continue on with the advisory group.  and with Council's CCTV technical experts to come up with the best programme over the next three years, both to look at the improvements in operation that people want to see, so some improved clarity on playback of footage, but also those camera changes where  We've worked out over time that some of the original camera choices, in particular locations, are not as useful or as flexible as we'd like them to be. And so there's a plan to make some changes to make them more useful.  So they might have been good for one purpose, but the cameras have proved not to be good for another purpose that the ComSafe people would also like to use them for. So hence the recommendations to change out some cameras.
speaker: manager

text: Brian, could I just ask you at that particular point, in the original contract that we signed with the people that did the cameras,  Is there any room or any comeback from them? I mean, did they perform? Is there any grounds for us to say, well, you know, you set this up, you told us this, but it's not what it seemed? Or are we on our own at this? Can you tell me that, please?
speaker: chairperson

text: Yeah, so certainly our contractor did perform. They did meet the specifications of the contract. And on the whole, we've been very happy with their performance. I think what has happened is that with experience, we have worked out that some of our earlier choices and camera types and things like that, we have changed our mind about what we want.  So, you know, in some of the very early thinking, we put in a couple of cameras that could read number plates, thinking, well, they might be useful, they might not be. But in, you know, in the ensuing three years, we've determined that actually having more cameras capable of reading number plates would be a good thing. And, you know, police have reinforced that they'd like to see more of that. And that sort of approach is happening across the country. WIPAR is not an outlier.  in that area. So, you know, some of our requirements have changed. So, hence, you know, why we have got that advisory team back together to look at those technical requirements, drill into them and see where we can improve on the things that we do.
speaker: manager

text: Yeah. And Brian, is this upgrade  that we're looking to do, is it dependent on NZTA money? And if it is, are we still waiting for confirmation of money from NZTA before we proceed?
speaker: chairperson

text: So this is, these Improvement Works are funded from the LTP, and that includes money that we've got confirmation now, 51% subsidy from Waki Kotahi.
speaker: manager

text: Oh, thank you. That's great. Roger.
speaker: chairperson

text: Yes, thank you, Mr. Chair. Brian, yes, I understand the distinction between what is the basic request in this paper and the ongoing operational improvements. I think the last meeting that we had on this subject, there was suggestion that a technical expert based in Auckland was going to come in and Zoom in to make recommendations as to how we could improve  the quality of the playback requirements. Have we got a time frame on that? Because my understanding was that that was going to be treated with distinct urgency. So we should be starting to see at least some action defined in that regard.
speaker: rogergordon

text: Yes, so there is action there, Roger. We've had, as a wider group, we've had one meeting with that expert team, or there's a lot of industry experts actually on that team from different companies. So we've had one meeting as a wider group.  And we've had one online meeting as a smaller technical group. And just before this meeting this morning at 8.30, Sergei and I had another short meeting with one of those technical advisors.  Yep, treating that with urgency and we're certainly looking for that additional assistance in framing these improvements and make sure that we are, you know, everything we do from here on in we've got a really good understanding of all of the implications of the different types of technology we use and making sure that any new cameras we install and any  work we do on, whether it's the radio frequency of communications and things like that, that we're making sure we get the best quality we're able to with the type of system we have.
speaker: manager

text: Yeah, all due respect to that answer, though, Brian, my question was, do we have a time frame within which we're going to see some improvements? I realise it's meetings, meetings and meetings, but at some stage, we should expect to have some plan of action going forward. So can you put a time frame on that?
speaker: rogergordon

text: Yeah, well, within the next couple of weeks, we'll have that plan of action. But then how quickly we can implement it is really going to be down to, I think, COVID lockdowns and things like that, because pretty much all of our experts who do this work for us are based in Auckland.
speaker: manager

text: OK, would appreciate to see that report when you've defined that plan of action and look forward to it being within a couple of weeks. Thank you, Brian. Thanks, Brian.

text: Good morning, Hazel, you have a question then, Mike? Well, yes, I do.

text: And listening to all the comments, and thanks very much, Brian, and team for this report, but I have not got a problem with the costs of putting in these safety elements into our system. I don't even use that pedestrian crossing in Kihikihi Main Street because I'm better to go on my own judgment further up the road. So I have no objection whatsoever to our ratepayers' money going towards our safety in the district and not be quibbling over that.

text: Yes, we will try and do that, as long as the camera is still in good condition. I mean, these cameras, they do have a life. And when they get near to the end of their life, we won't be putting back or trying to reuse old cameras that only have a short remainder life. Yep.

text: Yeah, through the chair. Just a couple of questions there, Brian. So, again, thank you for the report and also all the comments that have come through from the councillors. This is my first question.

But if it's not, if it's just a straight capital project by council, then there may not be funding for it.  Certainly, the funding here that we're making changes to the existing camera system and expansion of the existing camera system has got subsidy, but some of those new intersections, like the C2-C3 intersection, doesn't have government subsidy, so there wouldn't be a subsidy on a camera in store.

text: Right, thanks. And just one secondary question, I think you maybe have answered it. When they come to end of life, is that cost, because like you say, the cost of the camera is actually the small bit, the infrastructure is the big bit, is that cost of just the camera back on us and the new installation?

text: Tab nine, we should have Martin Mould on there talking about the Cambridge Wastewater Treatment Plant. Morning, Martin.
speaker: chairperson

text: Good morning, can you see me?
speaker: martinmould

text: Not at the moment, but I shall go on to speak.
speaker: loubrown

text: Aha, yes.
speaker: chairperson

text: I've appeared. It is you. Good morning Chair and Councillors. So this report is a follow up from the workshop we did on the preferred option  for the Cambridge Wastewater Treatment Plant treatment options. So I won't go into too much detail other than a quick read of the exact summary. So obviously the short-term consent was granted for the Cambridge Wastewater Treatment Plant in 2019. And the conditions of that consent require the plant to be upgraded by 2026. So we've participated in the sub-regional business case, looking at options for boundaryless approach,  for waste water treatment across the southern Hamilton's, southern Waikato district and Waipa DC. The outcome of this business case is indicating that a standalone plant is the most efficient solution for Cambridge. The new plant will be required to meet significantly more stringent consent conditions for the proposed new discharge. This report follows on from our council workshop on the 23rd of September.  which provided an overview of the four options identified for further modeling to determine the preferred treatment trend for the new plant. An option, which was option two, incorporating a membrane bioreactor configured for biological phosphorus removal meets all the required criteria, minimizes chemical consumption, thereby reducing risk of future cost escalations.  has moderate electrical consumption, low greenhouse gas emissions, low capital costs, and low whole of life costs, and is recommended for adoption. All four options assess significantly reduced greenhouse gas emissions when completed to those from the current wastewater treatment plant. So the presentation and the report is attached to the agenda, and there's a sort of summary of that in the report, but happy to take any questions from that.
speaker: martinmould

text: Yeah, thanks, Martin. We had a very good hour on this with some really good searching questions. Is there any additional stuff gone in since our workshop, Martin, or any ins or outs or any changes that we should be aware of?
speaker: chairperson

text: No, there's been some good questions from you all. So I was certainly looking at some of those things. And one was from Claire was around the greenhouse gas emissions and carbon pricing to try and  fund the project, so we'll certainly be looking into those options going forward. Thank you.
speaker: martinmould

text: Roger.
speaker: chairperson

text: Thank you, through you, Mr Chair. Thanks, Martin. A question which I can't remember if we talked about last time, but given the fact that we've adopted this particular option, and knowing that there's a limited term to the short-term  consent. What's the timeframe for the completion of this option against that time that we have on the consent?
speaker: rogergordon

text: So the plan, the plan is to have the treatment plant completed by 2026. It's a bit of it's a it's a tall order, but but we're on target moment. We're currently in the consent phase. So we're putting all our documents together to submit  submit a consent by the end of the third quarter of next year, we'll have submitted our consent. In the meantime, we'll continue with the design, the detailed design of the upgrade. So we're ready to go to market as soon as we've got our consent, which will then give us a two to three year window to build, which is probably the time required to do that.
speaker: martinmould

text: You said it's a big ask to complete it in that five years. What actually happens if we don't?
speaker: rogergordon

text: Then we don't meet our consent conditions and are liable to further actions from the regional council. One would assume if we're well underway and it's been built and not yet finished, then that wouldn't be too severe. But we've made promises to our stakeholders that we will  have that plant running by 2026. So we wanna try and keep to that promise.
speaker: martinmould

text: Good, thanks Martin.
speaker: rogergordon

text: Anybody else that's not on screen that wants to ask any more questions? Okay, I think we're good to go. There's a recommendation A and B to accept the report from Martin and the deserved delivery approves the option to membrane bioreactor. So it's really important to get, Roger?
speaker: chairperson

text: So move.
